55137.title: Reclining Male Nude with Extended Leg
55137.description: Medium and support language now in use was approved by Corning curator and modern/contemporary glass specialist Tina Oldknow, Nov. 2013: "blown and hot-worked glass with hot-applied glass cane drawing, sandblasted"; Hot worked colorless glass male nude with direct drawing technique in blue, sandblasted and acid etched
55137.credit_line: Gift of Marilyn and Eugene Glick
55137.medium_support: blown and hot-worked glass with hot-applied glass cane drawing, sandblasted
55137.inscription: Signed, inscribed, and dated, underside, near top of figure's right thigh: Richard Jolley / Reclining Male [text obstructed] / Extended Leg 90

25100.title: Transvestite at her Birthday Party, New York
25100.credit_line: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in Honor of Mrs. H. L. Conant and Miss Joan D. Weisenbergr
25100.inscription: signed and inscribed verso, U.R.: 3/75 / TRANSVESTITE AT HER BIRTHDAY PARTY NYC, 1969 / NEIL SELKIRK [Printer] / Doon Arbus

extended_text.content:
Diane Arbus is renowned as one of the most influential photographers of her generation. Arbus turned her camera toward people who were often overlooked or on the fringes of mainstream society, creating memorable portraits with a distinct psychological charge.

Arbus was influenced by predecessors such as Weegee, a photographer who worked in New York from the 1940s to 1960s and was famed for capturing images of life on the street and those outside the cultural mainstream. In contrast to Weegee’s spontaneous street photography, Arbus chose to carefully compose her images, often developing a rapport with her sitters.

In this photograph, Arbus poignantly contrasts the pose of her sitter, who is shown reclining on a bed like a modern-day Venus or Madame de Pompadour, with the humble surroundings. Similarly, the exuberance of the subject’s expression finds a counterpoint in the way her smile reveals missing teeth.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

14007.title: projectile point
14007.creation_notes: "Earliest" date = 3000 BC because that is the earliest artifact from the Native Arts of the Americas collection known to have been made in the (now) US;"Latest" date = accession year. These fields are filled out somewhat arbitrarily for search purposes only; the Earliest/Latest dates were not provided by Mellon Curator Dr. Christian Feest and should not be used or provided outside the IMA.
14007.credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Earl C. Townsend, Jr.
14007.provenance:
Earl C. Townsend, Jr. [1914-2007] and Emily Townsend [1920-1988] {1}, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the John Herron Art Institute, now the Indianapolis Museum of Art, in 1964.

{1} also known as Elizabeth Emily MacNab Townsend

4078.title: wedding dress
4078.title_notes: wedding dress: a) bodice, b) skirt, c) sash, d) photo of bride
4078.description:
wedding dress: a) bodice, b) skirt, c) sash, d) photo of bride
made of beige ribbed silk (faille)
4078.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Ralph C. Vonnegut
4078.provenance:
Lulu M. Osterman {1}; Mrs. Ralph C. Vonnegut {2} (Natalia Beck) Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art (December, 1970).
1} worn by Lulu M. Osterman in her marriage to Walter Jerome Goodall, 1892
{2} Ralph Clemens Vonnegut Jr. is the grandchild of Walter Jerome Goodall and Lulu M. Osterman Goodall

extended_text.content: Lulu Ostermann Goodall wore this gown of silk faille at her wedding October 11, 1892. It is typical a typical design of the period with asymmetrical draping and applied ruffles.
